description: From Middle English habit, from Latin habitus (“condition, bearing, state, appearance, dress, attire”), from habeō (“I have, hold, keep”). Replaced Middle English abit, from Old French abit, itself from the same Latin source. Displaced native Old English þēaw.

entries.meaning: An action performed on a regular basis.
An action performed repeatedly and automatically, usually without awareness.
examples: By force of habit, he dressed for work even though it was holiday.

entries.meaning: A long piece of clothing worn by monks and nuns.
examples: It’s interesting how Catholic and Buddhist monks both wear habits.

entries.meaning: A piece of clothing worn for a specific activity; a uniform.
examples: The new riding habits of the team looked smashing!
There are, among the statues, several of Venus, in different habits.

entries.meaning: (botany, mineralogy) Form of growth or general appearance and structure of a variety or species of plant or crystal.

description: From Middle English habiten, from Old French habiter, from Latin habitāre, present active infinitive of habitō (“I dwell, abide, keep”), frequentative of habeō (“I have, hold, keep”); see have.

verbs.description: habit (third-person singular simple present habits, present participle habiting, simple past and past participle habited)
